items.title: I can explain that nuclear energy results from the conversion of mass to energy
items.what: Nuclear energy is released when a small amount of mass is converted into energy according to Einstein's equation E = mc². Both fission and fusion reactions involve this mass-to-energy conversion.
items.why: This principle explains why nuclear fuels contain so much more energy per kilogram than chemical fuels, and forms the basis for understanding all nuclear technologies.
items.example: When uranium-235 undergoes fission, about 0.1% of its mass is converted to energy. If 1.0 kg of uranium-235 completely fissions, 1.0 g of mass becomes 9.0 × 10¹³ J of energy.

subtopic.name: Energy-Mass Equivalence
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers Einstein's famous equation E = mc² and how it explains the enormous energy locked within matter. You will learn how nuclear reactions convert small amounts of mass into vast quantities of energy.
subtopic.why: Understanding energy-mass equivalence is fundamental to explaining how nuclear power plants and nuclear weapons work, and why nuclear fuels release millions of times more energy than chemical fuels like coal.

items.title: I can use E = mc² to calculate energy released from mass conversion
items.what: The equation E = mc² relates the energy released (E in joules) to the mass converted (m in kilograms) and the speed of light squared (c² = 9 × 10¹⁶ m² s⁻²).
items.why: Being able to calculate energy from mass difference allows you to quantify the enormous energy released in nuclear reactions and compare nuclear to chemical energy sources.
items.example: A nuclear bomb converts 0.7 g of mass to energy: E = (7 × 10⁻⁴)(9 × 10¹⁶) = 63 × 10¹² J = 63 TJ, equivalent to about 15 kilotonnes of TNT.

subtopic.name: Energy-Mass Equivalence
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers Einstein's famous equation E = mc² and how it explains the enormous energy locked within matter. You will learn how nuclear reactions convert small amounts of mass into vast quantities of energy.
subtopic.why: Understanding energy-mass equivalence is fundamental to explaining how nuclear power plants and nuclear weapons work, and why nuclear fuels release millions of times more energy than chemical fuels like coal.

items.title: I can compare the energy released by nuclear reactions versus chemical reactions
items.what: Nuclear reactions release approximately one million times more energy per kilogram than chemical reactions because the strong nuclear force is much stronger than electromagnetic forces binding electrons.
items.why: This comparison explains why a small uranium pellet can release as much energy as burning a tonne of coal, making nuclear energy so concentrated.
items.example: Burning 1.0 kg of coal releases 3.0 × 10⁷ J with a mass loss of 0.33 μg. Fissioning 1.0 kg of uranium-235 releases 9.0 × 10¹³ J with a mass loss of 1.0 g, about 3 million times more energy.

subtopic.name: Energy-Mass Equivalence
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers Einstein's famous equation E = mc² and how it explains the enormous energy locked within matter. You will learn how nuclear reactions convert small amounts of mass into vast quantities of energy.
subtopic.why: Understanding energy-mass equivalence is fundamental to explaining how nuclear power plants and nuclear weapons work, and why nuclear fuels release millions of times more energy than chemical fuels like coal.

items.title: I can explain the difference between chemical and nuclear burning of fuels
items.what: Chemical burning rearranges outer electrons (bound by electromagnetic force, a few eV). Nuclear burning rearranges nucleons (bound by the strong force, millions of eV). Both involve mass-to-energy conversion.
items.why: Understanding this distinction clarifies why nuclear fuels are so much more energy-dense and why nuclear reactions fundamentally differ from ordinary combustion.
items.example: In coal combustion, carbon and oxygen electrons rearrange. In uranium fission, the nucleus itself splits apart, releasing binding energy that was holding the nucleons together.

subtopic.what: This subtopic covers Einstein's famous equation E = mc² and how it explains the enormous energy locked within matter. You will learn how nuclear reactions convert small amounts of mass into vast quantities of energy.
subtopic.why: Understanding energy-mass equivalence is fundamental to explaining how nuclear power plants and nuclear weapons work, and why nuclear fuels release millions of times more energy than chemical fuels like coal.

items.title: I can describe the process of nuclear fission
items.what: Nuclear fission occurs when a heavy nucleus like uranium-235 absorbs a neutron, becomes unstable, and splits into two smaller nuclei (fission products) plus 2-3 neutrons and energy.
items.why: This process is the basis for nuclear reactors and weapons. The released neutrons can trigger further fissions, potentially creating a chain reaction.
items.example: When U-235 absorbs a neutron, it briefly becomes U-236, then splits into barium-141 and krypton-92, releasing 3 neutrons and about 200 MeV of energy.

subtopic.name: Nuclear Fission
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the process of nuclear fission, where heavy unstable nuclei split into smaller, more stable nuclei. You will learn about fissile materials, the role of neutrons, and how chain reactions develop.
subtopic.why: Fission is the process used in all current nuclear power plants and nuclear weapons. Understanding how it works is essential for informed discussions about nuclear energy and safety.

items.title: I can identify fissile and non-fissile materials
items.what: Fissile materials can sustain a chain reaction when bombarded with neutrons. Uranium-235 and plutonium-239 are fissile. Uranium-238 is non-fissile as it does not readily undergo fission.
items.why: Knowing which materials are fissile is essential for understanding why uranium must be enriched and why plutonium can be produced in reactors.
items.example: Natural uranium is 99.3% non-fissile U-238 and only 0.7% fissile U-235. Reactor fuel is typically enriched to 3.5-4.5% U-235, while weapons require over 90% U-235.

subtopic.name: Nuclear Fission
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the process of nuclear fission, where heavy unstable nuclei split into smaller, more stable nuclei. You will learn about fissile materials, the role of neutrons, and how chain reactions develop.
subtopic.why: Fission is the process used in all current nuclear power plants and nuclear weapons. Understanding how it works is essential for informed discussions about nuclear energy and safety.

items.title: I can explain what a chain reaction is and how it develops
items.what: A chain reaction occurs when neutrons released by one fission event cause further fissions in nearby nuclei, which release more neutrons, causing even more fissions in a self-sustaining process.
items.why: Chain reactions are the key to both controlled nuclear power and uncontrolled nuclear explosions. Understanding them is crucial for nuclear safety.
items.example: If each fission releases 2.5 neutrons on average and 2 of these cause new fissions, the number of fissions doubles each generation. After 80 generations, an enormous explosion occurs.

subtopic.name: Nuclear Fission
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the process of nuclear fission, where heavy unstable nuclei split into smaller, more stable nuclei. You will learn about fissile materials, the role of neutrons, and how chain reactions develop.
subtopic.why: Fission is the process used in all current nuclear power plants and nuclear weapons. Understanding how it works is essential for informed discussions about nuclear energy and safety.

items.title: I can distinguish between controlled and uncontrolled chain reactions
items.what: In a controlled chain reaction, exactly one neutron per fission causes another fission, maintaining steady power output. In an uncontrolled reaction, multiple neutrons cause multiple fissions, growing exponentially.
items.why: Nuclear reactors require controlled reactions for safe, sustained power generation. Nuclear weapons rely on uncontrolled reactions for explosive energy release.
items.example: In a power reactor, control rods absorb excess neutrons so only 1 of 2.5 neutrons causes another fission. In a bomb, all neutrons are allowed to cause fissions, leading to exponential growth.

subtopic.why: Fission is the process used in all current nuclear power plants and nuclear weapons. Understanding how it works is essential for informed discussions about nuclear energy and safety.

items.title: I can balance nuclear fission equations
items.what: In nuclear equations, the total number of protons (atomic number) and total number of nucleons (mass number) must be conserved on both sides of the equation.
items.why: Balancing nuclear equations allows you to identify unknown products and verify that proposed reactions obey conservation laws.
items.example: For ²³⁵U + ¹n → ¹⁴⁰Xe + ⁹⁴Sr + ?n: Nucleons: 235+1 = 140+94+?, so ? = 2 neutrons. Protons: 92+0 = 54+38+0, which balances.

subtopic.name: Nuclear Fission
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the process of nuclear fission, where heavy unstable nuclei split into smaller, more stable nuclei. You will learn about fissile materials, the role of neutrons, and how chain reactions develop.
subtopic.why: Fission is the process used in all current nuclear power plants and nuclear weapons. Understanding how it works is essential for informed discussions about nuclear energy and safety.

items.title: I can explain what critical mass means
items.what: Critical mass is the minimum amount of fissile material needed to sustain a chain reaction, where the rate of neutron creation by fission equals the rate of neutron loss through the surface.
items.why: Understanding critical mass explains why small amounts of fissile material are safe to handle but larger amounts can become dangerous, and why bomb design involves assembling subcritical masses.
items.example: A small sphere of U-235 is subcritical because too many neutrons escape through the surface. A larger sphere has less surface area relative to volume, so more neutrons stay inside to cause fissions.

subtopic.name: Controlling Nuclear Reactions
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how chain reactions are controlled in nuclear reactors through critical mass management, moderators to slow neutrons, and control rods to absorb neutrons.
subtopic.why: Understanding these control mechanisms is essential for comprehending nuclear reactor design and safety systems that prevent accidents and enable peaceful use of nuclear energy.

items.title: I can describe how mass and shape affect criticality
items.what: Criticality depends on the ratio of volume to surface area. A sphere has the smallest surface area for a given volume, so spheres reach criticality with less mass. Flat shapes lose more neutrons and are safer.
items.why: This principle explains why nuclear weapons use spherical shapes and why reactor fuel is arranged in thin rods rather than large lumps.
items.example: A sphere of U-235 may be critical, but the same mass spread into a thin flat sheet is subcritical because neutrons escape easily through the large surface area.

subtopic.name: Controlling Nuclear Reactions
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how chain reactions are controlled in nuclear reactors through critical mass management, moderators to slow neutrons, and control rods to absorb neutrons.
subtopic.why: Understanding these control mechanisms is essential for comprehending nuclear reactor design and safety systems that prevent accidents and enable peaceful use of nuclear energy.

items.title: I can explain the difference between subcritical, critical, and supercritical states
items.what: Subcritical: neutron loss exceeds creation, reaction dies out. Critical: neutron loss equals creation, steady reaction. Supercritical: neutron creation exceeds loss, reaction grows exponentially.
items.why: Reactors operate at critical state for steady power. Bombs require supercritical conditions for explosion. Subcritical storage prevents accidents.
items.example: A reactor at startup raises control rods until it becomes critical (steady power). If it became supercritical, power would increase dangerously until safety systems responded.

subtopic.name: Controlling Nuclear Reactions
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how chain reactions are controlled in nuclear reactors through critical mass management, moderators to slow neutrons, and control rods to absorb neutrons.
subtopic.why: Understanding these control mechanisms is essential for comprehending nuclear reactor design and safety systems that prevent accidents and enable peaceful use of nuclear energy.

items.title: I can explain the role of moderators in nuclear reactors
items.what: Moderators slow down fast neutrons to thermal (slow) speeds without absorbing them. Slow neutrons are much more likely to be absorbed by U-235 and cause fission than fast neutrons.
items.why: Without moderators, most neutrons would be too fast to cause fissions efficiently, and the chain reaction could not be sustained in reactor fuel.
items.example: Water, graphite, and heavy water are common moderators. When a fast neutron collides with hydrogen in water, it loses energy like a billiard ball hitting another ball of similar mass.

subtopic.name: Controlling Nuclear Reactions
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how chain reactions are controlled in nuclear reactors through critical mass management, moderators to slow neutrons, and control rods to absorb neutrons.
subtopic.why: Understanding these control mechanisms is essential for comprehending nuclear reactor design and safety systems that prevent accidents and enable peaceful use of nuclear energy.

items.title: I can explain the role of control rods in nuclear reactors
items.what: Control rods contain materials like boron, cadmium, or hafnium that readily absorb neutrons. Inserting rods absorbs more neutrons, reducing the reaction rate. Withdrawing them allows the reaction to increase.
items.why: Control rods are the primary means of regulating reactor power and can be rapidly inserted to shut down a reactor in an emergency.
items.example: To increase power, operators slowly withdraw control rods, allowing more neutrons to cause fissions. In an emergency, all control rods drop fully into the core, absorbing neutrons and stopping the reaction.

subtopic.name: Controlling Nuclear Reactions
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how chain reactions are controlled in nuclear reactors through critical mass management, moderators to slow neutrons, and control rods to absorb neutrons.
subtopic.why: Understanding these control mechanisms is essential for comprehending nuclear reactor design and safety systems that prevent accidents and enable peaceful use of nuclear energy.

items.title: I can describe the basic components of a nuclear fission reactor
items.what: A fission reactor contains fuel rods (enriched uranium), a moderator (often water), control rods (neutron absorbers), coolant circuits (to extract heat), and containment structures (for safety).
items.why: Understanding reactor components helps explain how nuclear power plants generate electricity safely and what safety systems protect against accidents.
items.example: In a pressurised water reactor, water serves as both moderator and coolant. It circulates through the core, absorbs heat from fission, and transfers it to steam generators that drive turbines.

subtopic.name: Controlling Nuclear Reactions
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how chain reactions are controlled in nuclear reactors through critical mass management, moderators to slow neutrons, and control rods to absorb neutrons.
subtopic.why: Understanding these control mechanisms is essential for comprehending nuclear reactor design and safety systems that prevent accidents and enable peaceful use of nuclear energy.

items.title: I can describe the process of nuclear fusion
items.what: Nuclear fusion occurs when two light nuclei combine to form a heavier nucleus. The mass of the product is less than the total mass of the original nuclei, with the difference released as energy.
items.why: Fusion releases even more energy per kilogram than fission and produces no long-lived radioactive waste, making it a highly desirable future energy source.
items.example: In the Sun, hydrogen nuclei fuse to form helium. Four hydrogen atoms (total mass 4.032 u) become one helium atom (mass 4.003 u), with 0.029 u converted to 26.7 MeV of energy.

subtopic.name: Nuclear Fusion
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers nuclear fusion, where light nuclei combine to form heavier nuclei, releasing energy. You will learn how fusion powers the Sun and stars, and the challenges of achieving controlled fusion on Earth.
subtopic.why: Fusion is the energy source of the Sun and potentially offers nearly unlimited clean energy for humanity. Understanding fusion is essential for evaluating future energy technologies.

items.title: I can compare nuclear fusion and nuclear fission
items.what: Fission splits heavy nuclei into lighter ones. Fusion joins light nuclei into heavier ones. Both release energy through mass conversion, but fusion converts about 0.7% of mass versus 0.1% for fission.
items.why: Comparing these processes reveals why fusion is potentially more powerful and cleaner, and helps explain why achieving controlled fusion is so challenging.
items.example: A fission bomb using 1 kg of U-235 releases energy equivalent to 20 kt of TNT. A fusion bomb using 1 kg of hydrogen isotopes releases energy equivalent to 200 kt of TNT.

subtopic.name: Nuclear Fusion
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers nuclear fusion, where light nuclei combine to form heavier nuclei, releasing energy. You will learn how fusion powers the Sun and stars, and the challenges of achieving controlled fusion on Earth.
subtopic.why: Fusion is the energy source of the Sun and potentially offers nearly unlimited clean energy for humanity. Understanding fusion is essential for evaluating future energy technologies.

items.title: I can explain why fusion requires extreme temperatures
items.what: Hydrogen nuclei are positively charged and repel each other. Extreme temperatures (over 100 million kelvin) give nuclei enough kinetic energy to overcome this electrostatic repulsion and get close enough for the strong force to bind them.
items.why: This requirement explains why controlled fusion is so difficult to achieve on Earth and why it occurs naturally only in stars where gravity provides enormous pressure.
items.example: The Sun's core reaches 15 million kelvin, but its extreme pressure helps. Earth-based fusion reactors must reach 150 million kelvin to compensate for lower pressure.

subtopic.name: Nuclear Fusion
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers nuclear fusion, where light nuclei combine to form heavier nuclei, releasing energy. You will learn how fusion powers the Sun and stars, and the challenges of achieving controlled fusion on Earth.
subtopic.why: Fusion is the energy source of the Sun and potentially offers nearly unlimited clean energy for humanity. Understanding fusion is essential for evaluating future energy technologies.

items.title: I can describe how the Sun produces energy through fusion
items.what: The Sun converts 600 million tonnes of hydrogen into helium every second through nuclear fusion. About 4.2 million tonnes of this mass is converted to energy, producing 3.8 × 10²⁶ W of power.
items.why: Understanding stellar fusion explains where sunlight comes from and demonstrates the enormous scale of energy that fusion can produce.
items.example: In the proton-proton chain, hydrogen fuses through several steps: H-1 + H-1 → H-2, then H-2 + H-1 → He-3, finally He-3 + He-3 → He-4 + 2H-1.

subtopic.name: Nuclear Fusion
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers nuclear fusion, where light nuclei combine to form heavier nuclei, releasing energy. You will learn how fusion powers the Sun and stars, and the challenges of achieving controlled fusion on Earth.
subtopic.why: Fusion is the energy source of the Sun and potentially offers nearly unlimited clean energy for humanity. Understanding fusion is essential for evaluating future energy technologies.

items.title: I can explain the challenges of achieving controlled fusion on Earth
items.what: Controlled fusion requires confining plasma at extreme temperatures without it touching any material. Tokamaks use powerful magnetic fields to contain the plasma in a donut-shaped chamber.
items.why: Understanding these challenges explains why fusion power plants are not yet operational despite decades of research, and what progress is being made.
items.example: The ITER tokamak in France aims to produce 500 MW of fusion power from 50 MW of input heating. It uses superconducting magnets to confine deuterium-tritium plasma at 150 million kelvin.

subtopic.name: Nuclear Fusion
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers nuclear fusion, where light nuclei combine to form heavier nuclei, releasing energy. You will learn how fusion powers the Sun and stars, and the challenges of achieving controlled fusion on Earth.
subtopic.why: Fusion is the energy source of the Sun and potentially offers nearly unlimited clean energy for humanity. Understanding fusion is essential for evaluating future energy technologies.

items.title: I can define binding energy and mass defect
items.what: Binding energy is the energy required to separate a nucleus into individual nucleons. Mass defect is the difference between the mass of separated nucleons and the mass of the assembled nucleus.
items.why: These concepts explain why nuclei are stable and why nuclear reactions can release enormous energy when nucleons rearrange into more tightly bound configurations.
items.example: A helium-4 nucleus has mass 4.0026 u, but two protons and two neutrons separately have mass 4.0319 u. The mass defect of 0.0293 u corresponds to a binding energy of 28.3 MeV.

subtopic.name: Binding Energy
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers binding energy, mass defect, and the binding energy curve. You will learn why both fusion of light elements and fission of heavy elements release energy.
subtopic.why: The binding energy curve provides a unified explanation for why both fusion and fission release energy, and predicts which nuclear reactions will be energetically favourable.

items.title: I can interpret a binding energy curve
items.what: The binding energy curve plots average binding energy per nucleon against mass number. Iron-56 has the highest binding energy per nucleon (8.8 MeV), making it the most stable nucleus.
items.why: This curve explains why light elements release energy when they fuse (moving up the curve) and heavy elements release energy when they fission (also moving up the curve toward iron).
items.example: Hydrogen-2 has about 1.1 MeV per nucleon. Helium-4 has about 7.1 MeV per nucleon. When deuterium fuses to helium, the increase in binding energy per nucleon is released as kinetic energy.

subtopic.name: Binding Energy
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers binding energy, mass defect, and the binding energy curve. You will learn why both fusion of light elements and fission of heavy elements release energy.
subtopic.why: The binding energy curve provides a unified explanation for why both fusion and fission release energy, and predicts which nuclear reactions will be energetically favourable.

items.title: I can explain why fusion of light elements releases energy
items.what: Light elements have low binding energy per nucleon. When they fuse, the product has higher binding energy per nucleon. The difference is released as energy according to E = Δmc².
items.why: This explains why hydrogen fusion powers the Sun and why fusion of light elements up to iron is energetically favourable.
items.example: Deuterium (1.1 MeV/nucleon) and tritium (2.8 MeV/nucleon) fuse to form helium-4 (7.1 MeV/nucleon). The binding energy increases, releasing 17.6 MeV per reaction.

subtopic.name: Binding Energy
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers binding energy, mass defect, and the binding energy curve. You will learn why both fusion of light elements and fission of heavy elements release energy.
subtopic.why: The binding energy curve provides a unified explanation for why both fusion and fission release energy, and predicts which nuclear reactions will be energetically favourable.

items.title: I can explain why fission of heavy elements releases energy
items.what: Heavy elements like uranium have lower binding energy per nucleon than medium-mass elements. When uranium fissions, the fragments have higher binding energy per nucleon, releasing energy.
items.why: This explains why fission of heavy elements powers nuclear reactors and weapons, and why elements heavier than iron cannot release energy through fusion.
items.example: Uranium-235 has about 7.6 MeV per nucleon. Its fission products (around mass 95 and 137) have about 8.5 MeV per nucleon. The increase releases about 200 MeV per fission.

subtopic.name: Binding Energy
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers binding energy, mass defect, and the binding energy curve. You will learn why both fusion of light elements and fission of heavy elements release energy.
subtopic.why: The binding energy curve provides a unified explanation for why both fusion and fission release energy, and predicts which nuclear reactions will be energetically favourable.

items.title: I can calculate energy released using binding energy values
items.what: Energy released equals the total binding energy of products minus the total binding energy of reactants. This can be calculated from average binding energies and nucleon numbers.
items.why: This calculation method allows prediction of energy release for any nuclear reaction without needing precise mass measurements.
items.example: For D-T fusion: Reactants have (2×1.1) + (3×2.8) = 10.6 MeV total binding energy. Product He-4 has 4×7.1 = 28.4 MeV. Energy released = 28.4 - 10.6 = 17.8 MeV.

items.title: I can describe Australia's current relationship with nuclear energy
items.what: Australia has one-third of the world's uranium deposits and is the third-largest uranium producer, yet has no nuclear power plants. The OPAL reactor produces medical isotopes but not electricity.
items.why: Understanding this apparent contradiction helps frame the debate about whether Australia should develop nuclear power generation.
items.example: Australia exports uranium for nuclear power plants in other countries while generating most of its own electricity from coal and gas, contributing significantly to global CO₂ emissions.

subtopic.name: Nuclear Energy for Australia
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the historical, current, and potential future role of nuclear energy in Australia, including uranium mining, the OPAL reactor, nuclear waste issues, and debates about nuclear power generation.
subtopic.why: As citizens, understanding the scientific, economic, and social aspects of nuclear energy enables informed participation in important decisions about Australia's energy future and climate policy.

items.title: I can explain the purpose and function of Australia's OPAL reactor
items.what: OPAL is a 20 MW research reactor at Lucas Heights that produces radioisotopes for medical diagnosis and treatment, and neutron beams for scientific research. It uses 20% enriched uranium fuel.
items.why: OPAL demonstrates that Australia does use nuclear technology beneficially, and that nuclear reactors serve purposes beyond electricity generation.
items.example: About 75-80% of radioisotopes used in Australian nuclear medicine procedures come from OPAL. The average Australian will have at least two nuclear medicine procedures in their lifetime.

subtopic.name: Nuclear Energy for Australia
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the historical, current, and potential future role of nuclear energy in Australia, including uranium mining, the OPAL reactor, nuclear waste issues, and debates about nuclear power generation.
subtopic.why: As citizens, understanding the scientific, economic, and social aspects of nuclear energy enables informed participation in important decisions about Australia's energy future and climate policy.

items.title: I can discuss the advantages of nuclear power for electricity generation
items.what: Nuclear power produces no direct CO₂ emissions, provides reliable baseload power regardless of weather, requires relatively little land area, and uranium fuel is energy-dense and abundant in Australia.
items.why: Understanding the advantages helps evaluate whether nuclear power could help Australia meet climate targets and ensure energy security.
items.example: A 1000 MW nuclear plant prevents emission of 7-8 million tonnes of CO₂ per year compared to coal. France generates over 70% of its electricity from nuclear with low carbon emissions.

subtopic.name: Nuclear Energy for Australia
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the historical, current, and potential future role of nuclear energy in Australia, including uranium mining, the OPAL reactor, nuclear waste issues, and debates about nuclear power generation.
subtopic.why: As citizens, understanding the scientific, economic, and social aspects of nuclear energy enables informed participation in important decisions about Australia's energy future and climate policy.

items.title: I can discuss the disadvantages and concerns about nuclear power
items.what: Concerns include high construction costs, long build times (9+ years), radioactive waste storage for thousands of years, potential for accidents like Chernobyl and Fukushima, and weapons proliferation risks.
items.why: Understanding the disadvantages helps evaluate whether nuclear power's benefits outweigh its risks and costs compared to alternatives.
items.example: High-level nuclear waste contains 95% of total radioactivity and takes about 1200 years to decay to the radioactivity level of original uranium ore. Safe long-term storage remains challenging.

subtopic.name: Nuclear Energy for Australia
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the historical, current, and potential future role of nuclear energy in Australia, including uranium mining, the OPAL reactor, nuclear waste issues, and debates about nuclear power generation.
subtopic.why: As citizens, understanding the scientific, economic, and social aspects of nuclear energy enables informed participation in important decisions about Australia's energy future and climate policy.

items.title: I can compare nuclear power with renewable energy sources
items.what: Renewables like solar and wind have lower costs and faster construction times but are intermittent. Nuclear provides constant baseload power but costs more and takes longer to build.
items.why: Comparing these options helps evaluate which energy sources are most suitable for Australia's specific circumstances and climate goals.
items.example: CSIRO reports solar and wind with storage are now the lowest-cost new electricity generation in Australia. A major solar project takes 1-3 years to build versus 9+ years for nuclear.

subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the historical, current, and potential future role of nuclear energy in Australia, including uranium mining, the OPAL reactor, nuclear waste issues, and debates about nuclear power generation.
subtopic.why: As citizens, understanding the scientific, economic, and social aspects of nuclear energy enables informed participation in important decisions about Australia's energy future and climate policy.

items.title: I can analyse arguments for and against nuclear energy in Australia
items.what: The debate involves scientific, economic, social, and political factors. Different stakeholders emphasise different aspects based on their priorities and values.
items.why: Developing critical thinking skills to evaluate competing claims from various sources is essential for informed citizenship and decision-making.
items.example: The Minerals Council supports nuclear as zero-emission baseload power. The Climate Council argues renewables are cheaper and faster. Both positions involve scientific claims that can be evaluated.
